description:
Eimeria praecox is a species of apicomplexan parasite that belongs to the genus Eimeria. Eimeria are single-celled, obligate intracellular parasites that infect a wide range of vertebrate hosts, including mammals, birds, and reptiles.

Eimeria praecox is primarily known to infect chickens (Gallus gallus domesticus), the most common host. It is one of the several Eimeria species that can cause coccidiosis, a significant disease in poultry production. The parasite has a complex life cycle that involves both asexual and sexual reproductive stages within the host's intestinal tract.

The oocysts (the infectious form) of E. praecox are typically ovoid or ellipsoidal in shape and measure around 20-25 micrometers in length. Upon ingestion by the host, the oocysts undergo excystation, releasing sporozoites that invade the host's intestinal epithelial cells. Inside the host cells, the parasites undergo multiple rounds of asexual replication (schizogony) and eventually form gametocytes, which then fuse to produce oocysts that are subsequently released in the host's feces, completing the life cycle.

Eimeria praecox is considered one of the less pathogenic Eimeria species in chickens, but it can still contribute to decreased growth performance and production efficiency in infected birds. Effective management and control of coccidiosis, including the use of anticoccidial drugs and vaccines, are crucial in modern poultry farming to maintain the health and productivity of the flocks.
